            Facts
            
                
                    Virginia spring-beauty is native to North America, and a popular spring-flowering plant in gardens. Its range extends to southern and western New England, where it is found in moist, deciduous forests, forest edges and meadows.
                
            
        

        
            Habitat
            
              
              
                Forest edges, forests, meadows and fields
              
              
            
        

    

    
                New England distribution

            From
                Flora Novae Angliae dichotomous key
            
                3. 
      Claytonia virginica
      L. N
      Virginia spring-beauty. 
      Claytonia virginica L. var. 
      hammondiae (Kalmbacher) Doyle, Lewis, & Snyder; 
      C. robusta (Somes) Rydb. 
      •
      CT, MA, RI, 
      VT; southern and western New England. Mesic, deciduous forests, forest edges, meadows.
                
            
        
    

        
    

    

        
            Native to North America?
            Yes
        

        
        
        
            Sometimes confused with
            
            
                Claytonia caroliniana:
                leaf blades broad-oblanceolate to oval, mostly 10-30 mm wide, and bract subtending the lowest flower relatively weak (vs. C. virginica, with the leaf blades linear to narow-oblanceolate, 2-15 mm wide, and bract subtending the lowest flower stalk relatively firm).
            
            
        
        
        

        
        
        
            Synonyms
            
            
                Claytonia robusta (Somes) Rydb.
            
                Claytonia virginica L. var. hammondiae (Kalmbacher) Doyle, Lewis, & Snyder
